title: Saxon Shore Way Walking Route

images.title: Richard Dorrell / Orchard on Saxon Shore Way, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Orchard on Saxon Shore Way. The public footpath actually goes diagonally through this orchard, but I opted for an easier route round the edge. The pair of cottages are in Horsham Lane. I believe the trees to be pear.

images.title: Glyn Baker / Saxon Shore Way, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: This is the junction of the Saxon Shore Way and a footpath to Beckley Hill then on to Church Street. The Higham Saltings are on the south bank and the Coryton Oil Refinery storage tanks can be seen on the north.

images.title: Nick Smith / Warning sign on the Saxon Shore Way, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Warning sign on the path. Sign to warn of underwater pipes on the River Stour which is just to the right in the picture.

images.title: Nigel Chadwick [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridge on the path at Swalecliffe

images.title: Richard Dorrell / Ponds beside the Saxon Shore Way, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Ponds beside the path near Iwade

images.title: Nick Smith / Route of Saxon Shore Way ahead, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Along the River Stour near Minster

images.title: Philip Halling / Above the White Cliffs
images.caption: Above the White Cliffs. The trail follows at coastal path above the White Cliffs, here it is approaching St Margaret's at Cliffe.

images.title: Colin Smith / Oare Creek
images.caption: Oare Creek Yachts are left high and dry in the boatyards on the eastern bank of the creek at low tide. On the west bank, the sea wall path is part of the Saxon Shore Way.

description: Explore Kent's ancient coastline as you visit Iron Age hill forts, cathedrals, Martello towers, historic ports and castles on this incredible 160 mile walk. The route passes through two Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty, numerous Sites of Special Scientific Interest and several Nature Reserves. The walk begins on the Thames at Gravesend and heads through Faversham, Deal, Dover and Rye to the finish point at Hastings .
